greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Alphabetical value of n in its Roman numerals-based representation.
comment: This uses "modern" (i.e. medieval) Roman numerals; the ancient Romans did not use prefixed letters to subtract. One sometimes sees e.g. "IL" for 49, but this is not standard; the standard representation encodes each digit separately. Sequence is finite since Roman numerals are only defined up to 3999. (There is an extension using underlined letters up to 3999999, but that's still finite.) - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Jul 26 2006
link: Jeremy Gardiner, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..3999
example: a(12) corresponds to XII whose alphabetical value is 24 + 9 + 9 = 42.
results.author: _Tanya Khovanova_, Jul 23 2006
ext: More terms from _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Jul 26 2006
